exampleSentence: Olá! Como você está hoje?
exampleTranslation: Hello! How are you today?
contextNotes: The most common and versatile way to say 'hello' in Portuguese, suitable for all situations, formal or informal.

exampleSentence: Bom dia a todos, espero que tenham dormido bem.
exampleTranslation: Good morning everyone, I hope you slept well.
contextNotes: Used from sunrise until approximately noon (or sometimes until lunch time). Often shortened to just 'Dia!' in very informal settings in Brazil.

exampleSentence: Boa tarde, senhor. Posso ajudá-lo?
exampleTranslation: Good afternoon, sir. Can I help you?
contextNotes: Used from noon until sunset or the start of the night (around 6-7 PM). In Portugal, it strictly means 'Good afternoon'.

exampleSentence: Boa noite! Foi um prazer conhecê-lo.
exampleTranslation: Good evening! It was a pleasure meeting you.
contextNotes: Used both when greeting someone in the evening (after sunset) and when saying farewell before going to sleep.

exampleSentence: Tenho que ir agora. Tchau!
exampleTranslation: I have to go now. Bye!
contextNotes: A very common, informal way to say goodbye, borrowed from Italian ('ciao').

exampleSentence: Preciso sair, mas voltarei em breve. Até logo!
exampleTranslation: I need to leave, but I'll be back soon. See you later!
contextNotes: A polite and common way to say goodbye when you expect to see the person again, even if the timing is vague.

exampleSentence: E aí, João? Como vai a família?
exampleTranslation: What's up, João? How is the family?
contextNotes: A slightly more informal alternative to 'Como você está?' Often used in Brazil.

exampleSentence: Meu nome é Ana. Prazer em conhecê-lo.
exampleTranslation: My name is Ana. Pleasure to meet you.
contextNotes: A common abbreviation of 'É um prazer conhecê-lo' (It is a pleasure to meet you). Highly versatile in introductions.

exampleSentence: Obrigada pela ajuda! — De nada.
exampleTranslation: Thank you for the help! — You're welcome.
contextNotes: The standard response when someone thanks you. Literally means 'of nothing'.

translation: Yes, certainly / How may I help you?
exampleSentence: O senhor está procurando algo? Pois não?
exampleTranslation: Are you looking for something? Yes, certainly / How may I help you?
contextNotes: Primarily used in Brazil, especially in customer service or when answering a phone call, indicating readiness to assist. Can also be used to confirm understanding.

exampleSentence: Com licença, preciso passar. Onde fica o banheiro?
exampleTranslation: Excuse me, I need to pass. Where is the bathroom?
contextNotes: Used both to ask permission to pass or interrupt, and to politely ask for attention (like 'Excuse me, waiter').

exampleSentence: Saudações a todos os presentes nesta reunião.
exampleTranslation: Greetings to all those present at this meeting.
contextNotes: A formal or written way to address a group or begin a formal letter, rarely used in casual spoken conversation.

exampleSentence: Muito obrigado pela sua paciência.
exampleTranslation: Thank you very much for your patience.
contextNotes: Crucially, the speaker must match the ending to their own gender: men say 'Obrigado'; women say 'Obrigada'.

exampleSentence: Prezada Senhora Silva, escrevo para confirmar a reunião.
exampleTranslation: Dear/Esteemed Mrs. Silva, I am writing to confirm the meeting.
contextNotes: Used exclusively in formal written correspondence (emails, letters) as a respectful salutation. Must agree in gender with the recipient.

exampleSentence: Aguardamos sua resposta. Cordialmente, [Seu Nome].
exampleTranslation: We await your reply. Cordially, [Your Name].
contextNotes: A very formal closing used in professional or official correspondence, indicating respect and politeness.

exampleSentence: Eu só tenho um real na carteira.
exampleTranslation: I only have one real in my wallet.
contextNotes: The number 'um' (masculine) changes to 'uma' (feminine) when counting feminine nouns (e.g., uma maçã - one apple). It also functions as the indefinite article 'a/an'.

exampleSentence: Preciso de dez ovos para a receita.
exampleTranslation: I need ten eggs for the recipe.
contextNotes: A foundational number. Note the 'z' sounds like 's' at the end of the word in many Brazilian accents, but retains a 'z' sound when followed by a vowel (e.g., dez anos).

exampleSentence: O ingresso custa cinquenta reais.
exampleTranslation: The ticket costs fifty reais.
contextNotes: Used frequently in prices and ages. The 'qu' is pronounced /kw/ as in 'quick'.

exampleSentence: A população da cidade é de dez mil pessoas.
exampleTranslation: The city's population is ten thousand people.
contextNotes: Unlike English, 'mil' does not require 'um' before it (you say 'mil' for 'one thousand'). In Portuguese, periods are used as thousands separators and commas as decimal separators.

exampleSentence: Ele foi o primeiro a chegar na fila.
exampleTranslation: He was the first one to arrive in the line.
contextNotes: This is an ordinal number. It must agree in gender and number: primeiro (m. sing.), primeira (f. sing.), primeiros (m. plural), primeiras (f. plural).

exampleSentence: Dois é um número par.
exampleTranslation: Two is an even number.
contextNotes: When referring to numbers, 'par' means even. As a noun, it means 'pair' (e.g., um par de sapatos - a pair of shoes). Its opposite is 'ímpar' (odd).

exampleSentence: Eu comi metade do bolo.
exampleTranslation: I ate half of the cake.
contextNotes: Always a feminine noun ('a metade'). When used with fractions, 'meio' (adjective/adverb) is also common, but 'metade' specifically means 'the half portion'.

exampleSentence: Você pode calcular o total da conta, por favor?
exampleTranslation: Can you calculate the total of the bill, please?
contextNotes: A regular -ar verb. Essential for any transaction or mathematical context. Related noun: 'cálculo' (calculation).

exampleSentence: A temperatura está abaixo de zero.
exampleTranslation: The temperature is below zero.
contextNotes: Used exactly like in English. When reading phone numbers or sequences, it is pronounced clearly.

exampleSentence: Vou comprar uma dúzia de pães frescos.
exampleTranslation: I am going to buy a dozen fresh rolls.
contextNotes: Commonly used when buying eggs, bread, or flowers in markets. It is a feminine noun.

exampleSentence: Qual é a percentagem de desconto que vamos ter?
exampleTranslation: What is the percentage of discount we are going to get?
contextNotes: In Brazil, 'porcentagem' is more common, although 'percentagem' is also correct, especially in Portugal. The symbol '%' is read as 'por cento'.

exampleSentence: Temos que multiplicar o valor por três.
exampleTranslation: We have to multiply the value by three.
contextNotes: One of the four basic arithmetic operations. The noun form is 'multiplicação' (multiplication).

exampleSentence: Sete é um número ímpar, não é divisível por dois.
exampleTranslation: Seven is an odd number; it is not divisible by two.
contextNotes: The opposite of 'par' (even). It is invariant in gender (used for both masculine and feminine nouns) but takes an 'es' in the plural (ímpares).

exampleSentence: O número de telefone tem dez algarismos.
exampleTranslation: The phone number has ten digits.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to the individual symbols used to represent numbers (0, 1, 2, etc.), often used in technical or formal contexts regarding sequences of numbers.

exampleSentence: A magnitude do problema financeiro é assustadora.
exampleTranslation: The magnitude of the financial problem is frightening.
contextNotes: While related to size and scale (numerical concepts), this word is used in abstract, formal, or scientific contexts, indicating the extent or importance of something, making it a higher-level vocabulary item.

exampleSentence: Qual é a sua cor favorita?
exampleTranslation: What is your favorite color?
contextNotes: The basic word for 'color.' It is always feminine in Portuguese.

exampleSentence: O carro é vermelho.
exampleTranslation: The car is red.
contextNotes: Like most color adjectives, it must agree in gender and number with the noun (e.g., 'A rosa é vermelha').

exampleSentence: O céu está azul hoje.
exampleTranslation: The sky is blue today.
contextNotes: Azul is one of the few color adjectives that does not change form for feminine nouns (e.g., 'A caneta é azul').

exampleSentence: Comprei uma camisa amarela.
exampleTranslation: I bought a yellow shirt.
contextNotes: Commonly used, especially when referring to the Brazilian national football team's jersey (A Amarelinha).

exampleSentence: As folhas das árvores são verdes.
exampleTranslation: The leaves of the trees are green.
contextNotes: Like 'azul,' 'verde' does not change form for feminine nouns.

exampleSentence: Ela usava um vestido branco.
exampleTranslation: She wore a white dress.
contextNotes: In Brazil, wearing white on New Year's Eve (Réveillon) is a tradition to symbolize peace.

exampleSentence: Meu gato é todo preto.
exampleTranslation: My cat is all black.
contextNotes: Must agree in gender (preto/preta). Often used metaphorically, similar to English.

exampleSentence: Gosto de flores roxas.
exampleTranslation: I like purple flowers.
contextNotes: In Portugal, 'roxo' is often used, but 'púrpura' is also common, especially for deep shades.

exampleSentence: A fruta é laranja.
exampleTranslation: The fruit is orange.
contextNotes: 'Laranja' is both the name of the color and the fruit. As a color, it is usually invariable (does not change gender/number).

exampleSentence: Esta tonalidade de azul é muito escura.
exampleTranslation: This shade of blue is very dark.
contextNotes: A formal term used when discussing variations or nuances within a single color.

exampleSentence: Prefiro o cinza claro ao escuro.
exampleTranslation: I prefer the light gray to the dark one.
contextNotes: Used to describe the lightness of a color (e.g., 'verde claro' - light green). Must agree in gender/number.

exampleSentence: Ele pintou a parede de marrom escuro.
exampleTranslation: He painted the wall dark brown.
contextNotes: The opposite of 'claro.' Also agrees in gender/number (escura, escuros, escuras).

exampleSentence: O artista usou um matiz vibrante na pintura.
exampleTranslation: The artist used a vibrant tint in the painting.
contextNotes: More technical or artistic term for color quality, often interchangeable with 'tonalidade' but implies a specific mixture.

exampleSentence: O dia estava cinzento e chuvoso.
exampleTranslation: The day was gray and rainy.
contextNotes: While 'cinza' is the standard in Brazil, 'cinzento' (which inflects for gender/number) is very common in Portugal.

exampleSentence: A paleta cromática da obra é impressionante.
exampleTranslation: The chromatic palette of the work is impressive.
contextNotes: A formal adjective used in art, design, or scientific contexts relating to color or the spectrum of colors.

exampleSentence: O que vamos fazer hoje à noite?
exampleTranslation: What are we going to do tonight?
contextNotes: A fundamental word for daily communication. In Brazilian Portuguese, the 'j' is pronounced like the 's' in 'measure'.

exampleSentence: Vamos viajar amanhã de manhã.
exampleTranslation: We are going to travel tomorrow morning.
contextNotes: The tilde (~) over the 'a' indicates a nasal sound, crucial for correct pronunciation.

exampleSentence: Eu estudei português ontem.
exampleTranslation: I studied Portuguese yesterday.
contextNotes: Like 'Amanhã', this word has a nasal vowel sound, indicated by the 'm' and 'e' combination.

exampleSentence: Que horas são agora?
exampleTranslation: What time is it now?
contextNotes: Used specifically when asking for the time ('Que horas são?'). The 'r' is often a soft tap or flap in BP.

exampleSentence: Espera um minuto, por favor.
exampleTranslation: Wait a minute, please.
contextNotes: Standard measure of time. Note that Portuguese nouns ending in 'o' are typically masculine.

exampleSentence: Tenho uma reunião importante esta semana.
exampleTranslation: I have an important meeting this week.
contextNotes: Used frequently. Days of the week (segunda-feira, terça-feira, etc.) derive from this concept.

exampleSentence: Meu aniversário é no próximo mês.
exampleTranslation: My birthday is next month.
contextNotes: The plural form is 'meses' ([ˈmezis]). The circumflex (^) indicates a closed vowel sound.

exampleSentence: O ano novo começa em janeiro.
exampleTranslation: The new year starts in January.
contextNotes: Be careful not to confuse 'ano' (year) with 'ânus' (anus), which has an accented vowel.

exampleSentence: Qual é a data de hoje?
exampleTranslation: What is today's date?
contextNotes: Refers specifically to a calendar date. In Portuguese, dates are typically written Day/Month/Year.

exampleSentence: Esta foi a década mais quente registrada.
exampleTranslation: This was the hottest decade recorded.
contextNotes: Used when discussing historical periods or trends spanning ten years.

exampleSentence: Precisamos seguir o cronograma do projeto rigorosamente.
exampleTranslation: We need to strictly follow the project timeline.
contextNotes: A common term in professional or academic settings when referring to a planned sequence of events or deadlines.

exampleSentence: A pontualidade é muito valorizada em reuniões de negócios.
exampleTranslation: Punctuality is highly valued in business meetings.
contextNotes: While Brazilians are often perceived as flexible with time, punctuality is expected in formal settings.

exampleSentence: As regras vigentes serão aplicadas até o final do ano fiscal.
exampleTranslation: The current rules will be applied until the end of the fiscal year.
contextNotes: Often used in legal, governmental, or bureaucratic contexts to refer to laws, contracts, or periods that are presently valid.

exampleSentence: A beleza da flor é efêmera, mas a memória dura.
exampleTranslation: The beauty of the flower is ephemeral, but the memory lasts.
contextNotes: A more literary or formal term used to describe something lasting for a very short time, often used philosophically or poetically.

exampleSentence: Não há precedente para tal atraso na história da empresa.
exampleTranslation: There is no precedent for such a delay in the company's history.
contextNotes: Used when referring to an event or ruling that occurred earlier and serves as an example or justification for later actions.

exampleSentence: Eu gostaria de um copo de água, por favor.
exampleTranslation: I would like a glass of water, please.
contextNotes: Essential word. In Brazil, you usually specify 'água mineral' (bottled water) or 'água da torneira' (tap water), though tap water is less commonly consumed in restaurants.

exampleSentence: Vamos tomar um café depois do almoço.
exampleTranslation: Let's have a coffee after lunch.
contextNotes: Coffee is deeply ingrained in Portuguese culture (both Portugal and Brazil). Often served strong and small (a 'cafezinho' in Brazil or 'bica' in Portugal).

exampleSentence: Preciso comprar pão fresco para o café da manhã.
exampleTranslation: I need to buy fresh bread for breakfast.
contextNotes: The word 'pão' is masculine. In Brazil, the common French roll is often called 'pão francês'.

exampleSentence: Nós vamos comer pizza hoje à noite.
exampleTranslation: We are going to eat pizza tonight.
contextNotes: A regular -ER verb. Used universally for consuming food.

exampleSentence: É importante beber muita água no verão.
exampleTranslation: It is important to drink a lot of water in the summer.
contextNotes: A regular -ER verb. While 'tomar' (to take) is sometimes used for drinks, 'beber' is the direct translation for the action of drinking.

exampleSentence: O arroz e feijão são a base da culinária brasileira.
exampleTranslation: Rice and beans are the basis of Brazilian cuisine.
contextNotes: Rice is a staple side dish, almost always served with 'feijão' (beans) at lunch and dinner in Brazil.

exampleSentence: Qual é a sua fruta favorita?
exampleTranslation: What is your favorite fruit?
contextNotes: Portugal and Brazil have a vast array of tropical fruits. Often consumed fresh or as juices ('sucos').

exampleSentence: Você prefere o seu chá com ou sem açúcar?
exampleTranslation: Do you prefer your tea with or without sugar?
contextNotes: Used for sweetening drinks and desserts. Be careful with the 'ç' which sounds like an 's'.

exampleSentence: Eu pedi um bife com salada mista.
exampleTranslation: I ordered a steak with mixed salad.
contextNotes: A common side dish. Note that 'salada de fruta' means fruit salad.

exampleSentence: Vamos pedir uns petiscos e uma cerveja no bar.
exampleTranslation: Let's order some appetizers and a beer at the bar.
contextNotes: Commonly used in Portugal (similar to Spanish 'tapas') and Brazil, referring to small portions of food served with drinks, like olives, fried shrimp, or cheese cubes.

exampleSentence: O segredo do prato é o tempero caseiro da minha avó.
exampleTranslation: The secret to the dish is my grandmother's homemade seasoning.
contextNotes: Refers to the mix of spices, herbs, and aromatics used to flavor food (e.g., garlic, onion, parsley). Essential for discussing cooking.

exampleSentence: O almoço é a refeição mais importante do dia no Brasil.
exampleTranslation: Lunch is the most important meal of the day in Brazil.
contextNotes: A general term for any meal (breakfast, lunch, dinner). The word 'comida' refers generally to food.

exampleSentence: Qual sobremesa você recomenda hoje?
exampleTranslation: Which dessert do you recommend today?
contextNotes: Literally means 'over the table.' Common desserts include 'pudim' (flan) and various sweets made with condensed milk.

exampleSentence: Fomos a uma vinícola para degustar os vinhos locais.
exampleTranslation: We went to a winery to taste the local wines.
contextNotes: More formal than 'provar' (to try/taste). Used specifically when sampling or appreciating the flavor profile of high-quality food or drink.

exampleSentence: Ele tem um paladar refinado para a culinária japonesa.
exampleTranslation: He has a refined palate for Japanese cuisine.
contextNotes: Refers to the physical sense of taste or one's ability to discern flavors, often used in sophisticated food or drink discussions.

exampleSentence: Eu gosto de comer uma maçã crocante de manhã.
exampleTranslation: I like to eat a crunchy apple in the morning.
contextNotes: One of the most common fruits globally. Used frequently in daily conversation and grocery shopping.

exampleSentence: As cenouras são boas para a visão.
exampleTranslation: Carrots are good for vision.
contextNotes: A staple vegetable. Often used in soups (sopas) and salads (saladas).

exampleSentence: O Brasil é um grande produtor de banana.
exampleTranslation: Brazil is a large producer of bananas.
contextNotes: Extremely popular and cheap in Brazil. Often eaten for breakfast or as a quick snack.

exampleSentence: Vamos fazer purê de batata para o jantar.
exampleTranslation: We are going to make mashed potatoes for dinner.
contextNotes: Refers to the common white/yellow potato. Sweet potato is 'batata-doce'.

exampleSentence: Quero um copo de suco de laranja natural.
exampleTranslation: I want a glass of natural orange juice.
contextNotes: Brazil is the world's largest exporter of orange juice. 'Laranja' also means the color orange.

exampleSentence: A salada tem tomate e alface.
exampleTranslation: The salad has tomato and lettuce.
contextNotes: Essential word for ordering salads or sandwiches (lanches).

exampleSentence: O molho de tomate estava delicioso.
exampleTranslation: The tomato sauce was delicious.
contextNotes: Used in nearly all Brazilian cooking. Pronunciation of the final 'e' as 'ee' is typical in Brazil.

exampleSentence: Você prefere maçã ou pêra?
exampleTranslation: Do you prefer apple or pear?
contextNotes: Common fruit, often found in fruit salads or eaten raw.

exampleSentence: Meu filho não gosta de comer brócolis cozido.
exampleTranslation: My son doesn't like to eat cooked broccoli.
contextNotes: The plural form 'brócolis' is also used for the singular in Portuguese.

exampleSentence: O suco de abacaxi é muito refrescante no verão.
exampleTranslation: Pineapple juice is very refreshing in the summer.
contextNotes: A key tropical fruit. Note that in Portugal, 'ananás' is often used, while 'abacaxi' is standard in Brazil.

exampleSentence: Ela adicionou beterraba ralada à salada.
exampleTranslation: She added grated beet to the salad.
contextNotes: Often consumed boiled or grated raw in salads in Brazil, known for its deep red color.

exampleSentence: Vamos preparar uma lasanha de berinjela hoje.
exampleTranslation: We are going to prepare an eggplant lasagna today.
contextNotes: A common ingredient in Mediterranean and vegetarian dishes in Portuguese-speaking countries.

exampleSentence: O agrião tem um sabor levemente picante.
exampleTranslation: Watercress has a slightly spicy flavor.
contextNotes: Less common than lettuce, but frequently used in soups and as a garnish in fine dining or traditional cooking.

exampleSentence: Precisamos ir ao hortifrúti comprar legumes frescos.
exampleTranslation: We need to go to the produce section to buy fresh vegetables.
contextNotes: A common Brazilian portmanteau combining 'hortaliças' (leafy greens/vegetables) and 'frutas' (fruits). Essential for navigating markets.

exampleSentence: Comprar produtos respeitando a sazonalidade garante melhor sabor e preço.
exampleTranslation: Buying produce respecting seasonality ensures better flavor and price.
contextNotes: A term used when discussing sustainable food choices, farming, or market supply fluctuation.

exampleSentence: Eu gosto de comer arroz e feijão.
exampleTranslation: I like to eat rice and beans.
contextNotes: One of the most fundamental verbs. In Brazil, 'arroz e feijão' (rice and beans) is the staple daily meal.

exampleSentence: O jantar está pronto na mesa.
exampleTranslation: Dinner is ready on the table.
contextNotes: Can be used as both the noun (o jantar) and the verb (jantar). Dinner is typically eaten later in Brazil than in many other countries (often 8 PM or later).

exampleSentence: Minha avó adora cozinhar para a família.
exampleTranslation: My grandmother loves to cook for the family.
contextNotes: The root of the word 'cozinha' (kitchen). Essential verb for the theme.

exampleSentence: Eu sempre tomo café da manhã antes de sair.
exampleTranslation: I always have breakfast before leaving.
contextNotes: Often shortened to just 'café'. It typically includes bread, cheese, ham, fruit, and coffee with milk.

exampleSentence: Por favor, me passe a faca para cortar o pão.
exampleTranslation: Please pass me the knife to cut the bread.
contextNotes: One of the three basic utensils (faca, garfo, colher).

exampleSentence: Qual tempero você usou neste frango?
exampleTranslation: What seasoning did you use in this chicken?
contextNotes: Refers broadly to herbs, spices, or prepared seasoning mixes. Garlic and onion are fundamental 'temperos' in Brazilian cuisine.

exampleSentence: Você pode me dar a receita desse bolo?
exampleTranslation: Can you give me the recipe for this cake?
contextNotes: Note that 'receita' also means 'prescription' when referring to medicine, but the context usually makes the meaning clear.

exampleSentence: Vamos fritar os ovos para o almoço rápido.
exampleTranslation: Let's fry the eggs for a quick lunch.
contextNotes: A very common cooking method in Brazil, often using vegetable oil.

exampleSentence: Este prato está muito saboroso!
exampleTranslation: This dish is very tasty!
contextNotes: A common and polite compliment to a cook. It changes gender: 'saborosa' for feminine nouns.

exampleSentence: Você deve refogar o alho e a cebola primeiro.
exampleTranslation: You should sauté the garlic and onion first.
contextNotes: A crucial step in preparing the base for many Brazilian dishes (like rice, beans, or stews), involving lightly frying aromatics in oil.

exampleSentence: Pedimos uns petiscos enquanto esperávamos o prato principal.
exampleTranslation: We ordered some appetizers while we waited for the main dish.
contextNotes: Used widely in bars ('botecos') and casual restaurants, often referring to things like 'pastel', 'coxinha', or small portions of fries/meat.

exampleSentence: É preciso bater a massa no liquidificador por dois minutos.
exampleTranslation: It is necessary to blend the batter in the blender for two minutes.
contextNotes: The term 'liquidificador' (blender) is a common household appliance used for making juices, vitamins, and batters.

exampleSentence: Não se esqueça de escorrer a água do macarrão.
exampleTranslation: Don't forget to drain the water from the pasta.
contextNotes: Used frequently when dealing with cooked pasta, vegetables, or canned goods.

exampleSentence: O chef preparou uma degustação de queijos regionais.
exampleTranslation: The chef prepared a tasting of regional cheeses.
contextNotes: More formal than just 'provar' (to try). Implies a structured sampling experience, often used in culinary reviews or specialized events.

exampleSentence: O vinho tinto tem um paladar complexo e encorpado.
exampleTranslation: The red wine has a complex and full-bodied palate.
contextNotes: Refers to the sophisticated ability to discern flavors, often used in descriptive writing about food and drink.

exampleSentence: A cadeira da cozinha é de madeira.
exampleTranslation: The kitchen chair is made of wood.
contextNotes: A very common, essential piece of vocabulary. Used for any standard seat with a back.

exampleSentence: Coloque os pratos na mesa de jantar.
exampleTranslation: Put the plates on the dining table.
contextNotes: Can refer to any type of table (dining, coffee, desk). 'Mesa de centro' is a coffee table.

exampleSentence: Vamos assistir ao filme sentados no sofá.
exampleTranslation: Let's watch the movie sitting on the sofa.
contextNotes: The word 'sofá' is universally used in both Brazil and Portugal. Note the accented 'á'.

exampleSentence: Minha cama é muito confortável.
exampleTranslation: My bed is very comfortable.
contextNotes: If referring to the mattress specifically, you would use 'colchão' (masculine noun).

exampleSentence: Guardo minhas roupas no armário do quarto.
exampleTranslation: I keep my clothes in the bedroom wardrobe.
contextNotes: This is a versatile word. It can mean a kitchen cabinet ('armário de cozinha') or a clothes wardrobe ('armário de roupas').

exampleSentence: Os livros estão na estante da sala.
exampleTranslation: The books are on the living room shelf.
contextNotes: Refers to a standalone unit or a fixed shelf. Often used specifically for books ('estante de livros').

exampleSentence: Há um espelho grande no banheiro.
exampleTranslation: There is a large mirror in the bathroom.
contextNotes: Essential bathroom or bedroom vocabulary. The 'lh' sound is similar to the 'li' in 'million'.

exampleSentence: Compramos um tapete novo para a sala.
exampleTranslation: We bought a new rug for the living room.
contextNotes: Refers to a smaller, movable rug. For wall-to-wall carpeting, the term is usually 'carpete' (though 'tapete' is sometimes used generally).

exampleSentence: As chaves estão na gaveta de cima.
exampleTranslation: The keys are in the top drawer.
contextNotes: A necessary term when describing storage units like chests of drawers ('cômoda') or desks ('escrivaninha').

exampleSentence: Preciso organizar as meias na cômoda.
exampleTranslation: I need to organize the socks in the chest of drawers.
contextNotes: Specifically refers to the piece of furniture with stacked drawers, typically found in a bedroom.

exampleSentence: Deixei meu celular em cima do criado-mudo.
exampleTranslation: I left my cell phone on top of the nightstand.
contextNotes: Literally translates to 'mute servant.' While this term is traditional and widely used in Brazil, some people now prefer the more descriptive 'mesa de cabeceira' (headboard table).

exampleSentence: Instalamos uma prateleira nova na lavanderia.
exampleTranslation: We installed a new shelf in the laundry room.
contextNotes: Distinguished from 'estante' (a unit). 'Prateleira' usually refers to a single, fixed board attached to a wall.

exampleSentence: A luminária de chão cria uma luz suave.
exampleTranslation: The floor lamp creates a soft light.
contextNotes: A general term for lighting devices. Can refer to a table lamp ('luminária de mesa') or a ceiling fixture.

exampleSentence: O aparador na entrada é perfeito para chaves e correio.
exampleTranslation: The console table in the entrance is perfect for keys and mail.
contextNotes: Refers to a long, narrow table often placed against a wall in a dining room or entryway for decorative or serving purposes.

exampleSentence: A mesa antiga tem detalhes em marchetaria complexa.
exampleTranslation: The antique table has complex marquetry details.
contextNotes: This term is used when discussing high-quality, antique, or custom-made furniture, referring to the decorative technique of inserting pieces of wood or other materials into a veneer.

exampleSentence: Minha mãe é muito carinhosa.
exampleTranslation: My mother is very affectionate.
contextNotes: One of the most essential family words. The tilde (~) indicates a nasal vowel sound.

exampleSentence: O meu pai trabalha muito.
exampleTranslation: My father works a lot.
contextNotes: Like 'Mãe', this is fundamental. Used universally across Portuguese-speaking countries.

exampleSentence: Tenho um irmão mais velho.
exampleTranslation: I have an older brother.
contextNotes: Uses the nasal diphthong 'ão'. The plural is 'irmãos' (brothers/siblings).

exampleSentence: Minha irmã e eu somos amigas.
exampleTranslation: My sister and I are friends.
contextNotes: Feminine form of sibling. Note the lack of the nasal 'o' at the end, unlike 'irmão'.

exampleSentence: Ele é o filho mais novo da família.
exampleTranslation: He is the youngest son in the family.
contextNotes: The 'lh' sound is a palatal lateral approximant, similar to the 'li' in 'million'.

exampleSentence: Nossa filha está na faculdade.
exampleTranslation: Our daughter is in college.
contextNotes: Used to refer to one's female offspring. Plural 'filhos' can mean 'children' (mixed gender).

exampleSentence: Vamos visitar meus avós no domingo.
exampleTranslation: We are going to visit my grandparents on Sunday.
contextNotes: The plural 'avós' (masculine form) refers to both grandmother (avó, closed 'o') and grandfather (avô, closed 'o').

exampleSentence: Meu tio mora no Brasil.
exampleTranslation: My uncle lives in Brazil.
contextNotes: The 't' before 'i' often sounds like 'ch' in Brazilian Portuguese (BP). In European Portuguese (EP), it is a harder 't'.

exampleSentence: Minha prima se casou no ano passado.
exampleTranslation: My cousin got married last year.
contextNotes: The masculine form is 'primo'. These terms are used frequently, as extended family is very important in Lusophone culture.

exampleSentence: Ele me escolheu para ser o padrinho do bebê.
exampleTranslation: He chose me to be the baby's godfather.
contextNotes: Godparents (Padrinhos e Madrinhas) hold a significant role, often acting as second parents or mentors, especially in Catholic traditions.

exampleSentence: O grau de parentesco deles é distante.
exampleTranslation: Their degree of kinship is distant.
contextNotes: A formal term used to describe the connection or blood relationship between individuals.

exampleSentence: Eles têm uma vida conjugal feliz.
exampleTranslation: They have a happy marital life.
contextNotes: Used primarily in formal or legal contexts when discussing the relationship between spouses (e.g., 'união conjugal' - marital union).

exampleSentence: A família demonstrou grande acolhimento aos recém-chegados.
exampleTranslation: The family showed great welcoming/acceptance to the newcomers.
contextNotes: While meaning 'shelter,' in a family context, it refers strongly to emotional acceptance, warmth, and hospitality.

exampleSentence: O vínculo entre mãe e filho é inquebrável.
exampleTranslation: The bond between mother and son is unbreakable.
contextNotes: A crucial word for describing emotional or legal ties, often used in psychology or relationship discussions.

exampleSentence: Os documentos exigem a identificação de ambos os progenitores.
exampleTranslation: The documents require the identification of both biological parents.
contextNotes: A highly formal term, usually reserved for legal, biological, or academic contexts, rarely used in casual conversation where 'pai' or 'mãe' suffice.

exampleSentence: Beber água é importante para a sua saúde.
exampleTranslation: Drinking water is important for your health.
contextNotes: Often used as a toast, similar to 'Cheers!' or 'To your health!'

exampleSentence: Eu sinto uma dor de cabeça forte.
exampleTranslation: I feel a strong headache.
contextNotes: Commonly combined with body parts (e.g., dor de estômago - stomach ache, dor nas costas - back pain).

exampleSentence: Preciso marcar uma consulta com o médico.
exampleTranslation: I need to schedule an appointment with the doctor.
contextNotes: In Brazil, 'doutor/doutora' is also frequently used to address a doctor, even if they don't hold a doctorate degree.

exampleSentence: O bebê está com febre alta.
exampleTranslation: The baby has a high fever.
contextNotes: To say someone 'has a fever,' use the construction 'estar com febre' (to be with fever).

exampleSentence: É essencial cuidar bem do seu corpo.
exampleTranslation: It is essential to take good care of your body.
contextNotes: A very basic and essential noun for describing physical state or appearance.

exampleSentence: Tome este remédio duas vezes ao dia.
exampleTranslation: Take this medicine twice a day.
contextNotes: 'Medicamento' is the formal term, but 'remédio' is the most common word used in daily conversation for pills or treatments.

exampleSentence: Quais são os seus principais sintomas?
exampleTranslation: What are your main symptoms?
contextNotes: Note that although it ends in '-a', 'sintoma' is a masculine noun.

exampleSentence: A vacina contra a gripe é anual.
exampleTranslation: The flu vaccine is annual.
contextNotes: Brazil has a robust public vaccination program (SUS), making this a very common and culturally relevant word.

exampleSentence: Uma alimentação saudável previne doenças.
exampleTranslation: A healthy diet prevents diseases.
contextNotes: Refers to the overall pattern of eating, not just a restrictive diet (which is often 'dieta').

exampleSentence: Tenho uma consulta marcada para amanhã de manhã.
exampleTranslation: I have an appointment scheduled for tomorrow morning.
contextNotes: While 'compromisso' means appointment generally, 'consulta' is specifically used for medical or professional consultations.

exampleSentence: A fisioterapia é crucial para a recuperação completa.
exampleTranslation: Physical therapy is crucial for complete recovery.
contextNotes: Used broadly, from recovering from illness ('recuperação da saúde') to recovering lost items.

exampleSentence: O médico pediu um exame de sangue completo.
exampleTranslation: The doctor requested a complete blood test.
contextNotes: This word is used both for academic tests and medical laboratory tests (e.g., raio-X - X-ray, ultrassom - ultrasound).

exampleSentence: A prevenção é sempre o melhor tratamento.
exampleTranslation: Prevention is always the best treatment.
contextNotes: A key concept in public health campaigns in Portuguese-speaking countries.

exampleSentence: Vitamina C ajuda a fortalecer a imunidade.
exampleTranslation: Vitamin C helps strengthen immunity.
contextNotes: Used frequently in discussions about nutrition and infectious diseases.

exampleSentence: O prognóstico inicial para o paciente era reservado.
exampleTranslation: The initial prognosis for the patient was reserved.
contextNotes: A formal, technical term usually heard or read in clinical settings or medical reports.

exampleSentence: Eu preciso de uma camisa nova para o trabalho.
exampleTranslation: I need a new shirt for work.
contextNotes: Refers generally to button-down shirts or blouses. T-shirts are usually called 'camiseta'.

exampleSentence: Estas calças azuis são muito confortáveis.
exampleTranslation: These blue pants are very comfortable.
contextNotes: Always used in the plural form in Portuguese, even when referring to one pair of pants.

exampleSentence: Ela comprou um vestido lindo para a festa.
exampleTranslation: She bought a beautiful dress for the party.
contextNotes: A common item, pronounced with a 'ch' sound for the 't' in many parts of Brazil (e.g., 'ves-CHEE-doo').

exampleSentence: Meus sapatos novos estão apertados.
exampleTranslation: My new shoes are tight.
contextNotes: General term for shoes. Sneakers are typically 'tênis'.

exampleSentence: Onde estão as minhas meias de lã?
exampleTranslation: Where are my wool socks?
contextNotes: Also used for stockings or hosiery, though specific terms exist for those (e.g., 'meia-calça').

exampleSentence: Está frio, leve o seu casaco.
exampleTranslation: It's cold, take your coat.
contextNotes: A versatile term covering both light jackets and heavier coats, depending on the region and context.

exampleSentence: Esqueci meu cinto em casa hoje.
exampleTranslation: I forgot my belt at home today.
contextNotes: A basic accessory. The verb 'cintar' means to belt or strap.

exampleSentence: Não se esqueça dos seus óculos de sol na praia.
exampleTranslation: Don't forget your sunglasses at the beach.
contextNotes: Literally 'glasses of sun'. 'Óculos' (glasses) is always plural.

exampleSentence: Preciso lavar minha roupa suja.
exampleTranslation: I need to wash my dirty clothes.
contextNotes: The general term for clothes. 'Vestuário' is a more formal term for apparel or attire.

exampleSentence: Ele trocou de roupa e vestiu o pijama.
exampleTranslation: He changed clothes and put on his pajamas.
contextNotes: Despite ending in '-a', this word is masculine in Portuguese (O pijama).

exampleSentence: Este vestido é feito de um tecido de seda macio.
exampleTranslation: This dress is made of a soft silk fabric.
contextNotes: Essential for discussing material quality. Related to the verb 'tecer' (to weave).

exampleSentence: Gosto muito da estampa floral desta saia.
exampleTranslation: I really like the floral print on this skirt.
contextNotes: Used to describe the design or graphic on clothing, distinct from the color ('cor').

exampleSentence: O ajuste do terno está perfeito no meu corpo.
exampleTranslation: The fit of the suit is perfect on my body.
contextNotes: Crucial when talking about tailoring or shopping. The verb is 'ajustar'.

exampleSentence: A qualidade da alfaiataria brasileira é reconhecida mundialmente.
exampleTranslation: The quality of Brazilian tailoring is recognized worldwide.
contextNotes: Refers both to the craft of tailoring and the shop where the tailor works ('alfaiate' is the tailor).

exampleSentence: Estou a renovar todo o meu guarda-roupa para o inverno.
exampleTranslation: I am renewing my entire wardrobe for the winter.
contextNotes: Compound word meaning 'keeps-clothes.' Used for both the collection of clothes and the piece of furniture (closet).

exampleSentence: Eu preciso de dinheiro para comprar o pão.
exampleTranslation: I need money to buy the bread.
contextNotes: This is the standard, general term for money in Portuguese. Often used interchangeably with 'grana' (slang) in informal contexts.

exampleSentence: Nós vamos comprar um presente para ela.
exampleTranslation: We are going to buy a gift for her.
contextNotes: A fundamental verb for shopping. Conjugated regularly. The noun form is 'a compra' (the purchase/shopping).

exampleSentence: Qual é o preço deste café?
exampleTranslation: What is the price of this coffee?
contextNotes: Essential for asking about costs. If you want to ask if something is cheap, use 'barato' (cheap/inexpensive).

exampleSentence: Posso pagar com cartão de crédito?
exampleTranslation: Can I pay with a credit card?
contextNotes: Brazilians use cards extensively. 'Cartão' alone usually refers to any card (credit, debit, or loyalty).

exampleSentence: Desculpe, não tenho troco para essa nota.
exampleTranslation: Sorry, I don't have change for that bill.
contextNotes: Crucial word when paying with cash. If you are asking for small coins/bills, you might specify 'dinheiro trocado'.

exampleSentence: Aquela loja vende roupas muito bonitas.
exampleTranslation: That store sells very beautiful clothes.
contextNotes: General term for a retail establishment. A large department store might be called 'loja de departamentos'.

exampleSentence: Eles estão oferecendo um bom desconto hoje.
exampleTranslation: They are offering a good discount today.
contextNotes: Always good to ask: 'Tem desconto?' (Is there a discount?). Sales are often advertised as 'Promoção'.

exampleSentence: Eu preciso pagar a conta antes de sair.
exampleTranslation: I need to pay the bill before leaving.
contextNotes: The verb used for settling any debt or purchase. Often followed by 'por' if specifying what is being paid for (e.g., 'pagar pela comida').

exampleSentence: A fila para o caixa está muito longa.
exampleTranslation: The line for the checkout is very long.
contextNotes: Refers both to the physical checkout point (o caixa) and the person working there (o/a caixa). In Portugal, the checkout area is often called 'a caixa'.

exampleSentence: Temos que manter o orçamento apertado este mês.
exampleTranslation: We have to keep the budget tight this month.
contextNotes: Used both for personal finance planning (budget) and for a formal quote provided by a service provider (estimate).

exampleSentence: O parcelamento sem juros é muito comum no Brasil.
exampleTranslation: Interest-free installment payment is very common in Brazil.
contextNotes: A crucial concept in Brazilian commerce. It allows customers to divide large purchases into monthly payments ('parcelas'). Often advertised as 'em 10x sem juros' (in 10 installments without interest).

exampleSentence: Guarde a nota fiscal para o caso de precisar trocar o produto.
exampleTranslation: Keep the receipt in case you need to exchange the product.
contextNotes: This is the official, government-mandated receipt used for tax purposes. While 'recibo' is sometimes used for simple proof of payment, 'nota fiscal' is the standard for retail purchases.

exampleSentence: O câmbio do dólar está muito volátil hoje.
exampleTranslation: The dollar exchange rate is very volatile today.
contextNotes: Used when discussing foreign currency exchange (casa de câmbio = exchange house). Also means 'gear shift' in automotive contexts.

exampleSentence: O rendimento da poupança está muito baixo atualmente.
exampleTranslation: The savings account yield is very low currently.
contextNotes: A versatile financial term. It can refer to personal earned income, but is most frequently used in finance to describe the return generated by an investment or savings.

exampleSentence: A manutenção da adimplência é crucial para obter crédito bancário.
exampleTranslation: Maintaining solvency is crucial for obtaining bank credit.
contextNotes: A formal, legal, and financial term. It refers to the state of having fulfilled all financial obligations on time. Its opposite, 'inadimplência,' is the state of default or non-payment.

exampleSentence: O professor de matemática é muito paciente.
exampleTranslation: The math teacher is very patient.
contextNotes: In Brazil, 'Professor' is the standard term for a teacher at any level (school or university). Use the appropriate gender ending (-a for female).

exampleSentence: A estudante está lendo um livro na biblioteca.
exampleTranslation: The student is reading a book in the library.
contextNotes: This word is gender-neutral; it refers to both male and female students. The article (o/a) determines the gender.

exampleSentence: Minha escola fica perto da minha casa.
exampleTranslation: My school is close to my house.
contextNotes: Used for primary and secondary education institutions. For university, the word 'universidade' is used.

exampleSentence: Você fez a lição de casa de ontem?
exampleTranslation: Did you do yesterday's homework?
contextNotes: While it means 'lesson,' it is very commonly used colloquially to mean 'homework' or 'assignment' (lição de casa).

exampleSentence: Por favor, pegue seu caderno e caneta.
exampleTranslation: Please take your notebook and pen.
contextNotes: Essential school supply vocabulary. Distinct from 'livro' (book).

exampleSentence: Eu quero aprender a falar português fluentemente.
exampleTranslation: I want to learn to speak Portuguese fluently.
contextNotes: A very regular -ER verb. Used for acquiring knowledge or skills.

exampleSentence: Temos uma prova de história amanhã.
exampleTranslation: We have a history test tomorrow.
contextNotes: The standard term for a quiz, test, or major exam in school settings in Brazil. Sometimes 'exame' is used, but 'prova' is more common.

exampleSentence: A sala de aula está cheia de alunos.
exampleTranslation: The classroom is full of students.
contextNotes: Literally 'room of class.' Essential phrase for navigating school environments.

exampleSentence: O período de matrícula para o próximo semestre começa em agosto.
exampleTranslation: The enrollment period for the next semester starts in August.
contextNotes: Refers to the administrative process of signing up for a course or school year.

exampleSentence: Minha disciplina favorita na faculdade era filosofia.
exampleTranslation: My favorite subject in college was philosophy.
contextNotes: In academic contexts, this means 'subject' (like History or Science). It can also mean 'discipline' (behavioral).

exampleSentence: Se você não passar, terá que fazer a prova de recuperação.
exampleTranslation: If you don't pass, you will have to take the retake exam.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to the process or opportunity given to students to pass a subject they failed, often involving extra classes or a second test.

exampleSentence: O currículo escolar foi atualizado este ano.
exampleTranslation: The school curriculum was updated this year.
contextNotes: Context is key: in education, it means 'curriculum.' Outside of school, it is the standard word for 'resume' or 'CV'.

exampleSentence: Haverá uma palestra sobre sustentabilidade no auditório.
exampleTranslation: There will be a lecture about sustainability in the auditorium.
contextNotes: Used for formal talks or presentations, often in a university setting or professional conference.

exampleSentence: A coordenação pedagógica revisou o material didático.
exampleTranslation: The pedagogical coordination reviewed the teaching material.
contextNotes: Relates to the theory and practice of teaching. Often used in administrative or academic discussions (e.g., 'projeto pedagógico').

exampleSentence: A política de inclusão escolar visa atender alunos com necessidades especiais.
exampleTranslation: The school inclusion policy aims to serve students with special needs.
contextNotes: A key concept in modern Brazilian educational policy, focusing on accessibility and integrating all students, regardless of background or ability.

exampleSentence: Eu preciso de um novo trabalho.
exampleTranslation: I need a new job.
contextNotes: The most common word for 'work' or 'a job'. Can be used as both the activity and the specific position.

exampleSentence: Ela conseguiu um emprego na área de TI.
exampleTranslation: She got a job in the IT field.
contextNotes: Often used specifically to refer to a formal job position or employment status.

exampleSentence: Meu chefe é muito exigente.
exampleTranslation: My boss is very demanding.
contextNotes: Used for both male and female bosses (o chefe, a chefe). The term 'Gerente' is also common for 'Manager'.

exampleSentence: Trabalho no escritório todos os dias.
exampleTranslation: I work in the office every day.
contextNotes: Refers to the physical location of the business or a specific room used for administrative work.

exampleSentence: Vou almoçar com meus colegas de trabalho.
exampleTranslation: I am going to have lunch with my coworkers.
contextNotes: Like 'chefe', it is used for both genders (o colega, a colega). 'Colega de trabalho' is the full term for coworker.

exampleSentence: O salário mínimo aumentou este ano.
exampleTranslation: The minimum wage increased this year.
contextNotes: Essential term for discussing compensation. Often used interchangeably with 'vencimento' (paycheck).

exampleSentence: Temos uma reunião importante às dez horas.
exampleTranslation: We have an important meeting at ten o'clock.
contextNotes: A common professional term. Note the nasal diphthong 'ão' at the end.

exampleSentence: Você precisa atualizar seu currículo para a vaga.
exampleTranslation: You need to update your résumé for the vacancy.
contextNotes: The standard term used when applying for jobs. Often shortened to 'CV' in writing, but pronounced 'currículo'.

exampleSentence: Estou ansioso pelas minhas férias de verão.
exampleTranslation: I am looking forward to my summer vacation.
contextNotes: Always used in the plural form in Portuguese, even when referring to one period of leave.

exampleSentence: Havia dez candidatos para a posição de gerente.
exampleTranslation: There were ten candidates for the manager position.
contextNotes: Must agree in gender: 'o candidato' (male applicant), 'a candidata' (female applicant).

exampleSentence: Ele está fazendo um estágio não remunerado.
exampleTranslation: He is doing an unpaid internship.
contextNotes: Crucial term in academic and entry-level professional settings. The verb is 'estagiar' (to intern).

exampleSentence: A empresa anunciou uma série de demissões.
exampleTranslation: The company announced a series of layoffs.
contextNotes: Refers to the act of leaving a job, whether voluntary ('pedir demissão' - to resign) or involuntary ('ser demitido' - to be fired).

exampleSentence: Minha jornada de trabalho é de oito horas por dia.
exampleTranslation: My workday is eight hours per day.
contextNotes: A formal term used to describe the length or structure of the official working period.

exampleSentence: O empreendedorismo está crescendo muito no Brasil.
exampleTranslation: Entrepreneurship is growing a lot in Brazil.
contextNotes: A modern and increasingly important concept in the Portuguese-speaking world, referring to starting new businesses.

exampleSentence: A remuneração total inclui benefícios e bônus.
exampleTranslation: The total compensation includes benefits and bonuses.
contextNotes: A more formal and encompassing term than 'salário', often used in legal documents or HR discussions to include all forms of payment and benefits.

exampleSentence: Moro em uma cidade grande e movimentada.
exampleTranslation: I live in a big and busy city.
contextNotes: A foundational word. Used broadly across all Portuguese-speaking countries. Always feminine.

exampleSentence: Qual é o nome desta rua?
exampleTranslation: What is the name of this street?
contextNotes: Essential for giving directions. Often combined with names, e.g., 'Rua da Praia' (Beach Street).

exampleSentence: Vamos nos encontrar na praça central.
exampleTranslation: Let's meet in the central square.
contextNotes: The 'praça' is often the social and commercial heart of smaller towns and neighborhoods in Brazil and Portugal.

exampleSentence: Meu bairro é muito tranquilo e seguro.
exampleTranslation: My neighborhood is very quiet and safe.
contextNotes: Refers to a specific residential or commercial area within a city. A key term for discussing location.

exampleSentence: Preciso do seu endereço completo para enviar a carta.
exampleTranslation: I need your full address to send the letter.
contextNotes: Crucial for practical matters like mail, delivery, or giving directions to a taxi driver.

exampleSentence: O mercado fica perto da minha casa.
exampleTranslation: The market is close to my house.
contextNotes: Used constantly for relative location. The 'de' contracts with articles (e.g., 'perto do parque').

exampleSentence: A praia é um pouco longe do hotel.
exampleTranslation: The beach is a little far from the hotel.
contextNotes: The opposite of 'perto de'. Also requires the 'de' preposition.

exampleSentence: O café fica na esquina da Avenida Brasil.
exampleTranslation: The café is on the corner of Brazil Avenue.
contextNotes: Essential for giving precise directions, especially in grid-like city layouts.

exampleSentence: Muitas pessoas preferem viver no interior, longe do barulho da capital.
exampleTranslation: Many people prefer to live in the countryside, far from the capital's noise.
contextNotes: Refers to areas outside the major coastal cities. Often associated with a quieter, more traditional lifestyle.

exampleSentence: Esta pequena localidade é famosa pelo seu vinho.
exampleTranslation: This small locality is famous for its wine.
contextNotes: More formal than 'lugar' or 'cidade'; often used in official documents or when referring to a specific, often smaller, geographic area.

exampleSentence: Os arredores da cidade oferecem trilhas maravilhosas.
exampleTranslation: The outskirts of the city offer wonderful trails.
contextNotes: Always used in the plural form. Refers to the area immediately surrounding a central point or city.

exampleSentence: Use o farol como ponto de referência para encontrar a casa.
exampleTranslation: Use the lighthouse as a reference point to find the house.
contextNotes: While it means 'reference,' it's frequently used in the context of directions as a 'ponto de referência' (landmark).

exampleSentence: O formulário exige que você preencha o tipo de logradouro (rua, avenida, praça).
exampleTranslation: The form requires you to fill in the type of public thoroughfare (street, avenue, square).
contextNotes: A bureaucratic or technical term for any public space where people circulate (street, avenue, alley). Rarely used in casual conversation.

exampleSentence: A topografia montanhosa da região dificulta a construção de estradas.
exampleTranslation: The mountainous topography of the region makes road construction difficult.
contextNotes: Refers to the detailed mapping or physical features of an area. Used in academic, engineering, or detailed geographical discussions.

exampleSentence: A confluência dos dois rios cria um ecossistema único.
exampleTranslation: The confluence of the two rivers creates a unique ecosystem.
contextNotes: While literally meaning where two things flow together (rivers), it is also used metaphorically or technically to describe the meeting point or junction of major avenues or geographical features.

exampleSentence: Preciso renovar meu passaporte antes da viagem.
exampleTranslation: I need to renew my passport before the trip.
contextNotes: Essential document for international travel. In Brazil, the 'passaporte' is issued by the Federal Police.

exampleSentence: O aeroporto de Lisboa é muito movimentado.
exampleTranslation: Lisbon's airport is very busy.
contextNotes: Used universally in Portuguese-speaking countries. Brazilians often shorten it colloquially to 'aero'.

exampleSentence: Comprei um bilhete de ida e volta para o Porto.
exampleTranslation: I bought a round-trip ticket to Porto.
contextNotes: While 'passagem' is also used for travel tickets (especially plane/long-distance), 'bilhete' is common for local transport, cinema, or general entry. In Brazil, 'ingresso' is often used for events.

exampleSentence: O ônibus para o centro atrasou dez minutos.
exampleTranslation: The bus to the center was ten minutes late.
contextNotes: This is the universal term in Brazil. In Portugal, the word 'autocarro' (ow-toh-KAH-rroo) is used instead.

exampleSentence: Vamos nos encontrar na estação de metrô.
exampleTranslation: We are going to meet at the subway station.
contextNotes: Also means 'season' (e.g., verão - summer), but in the context of travel, it refers to a transport hub.

exampleSentence: Minha mala está muito pesada para a viagem.
exampleTranslation: My suitcase is too heavy for the trip.
contextNotes: Refers to a single piece of luggage. The collective term for luggage is 'bagagem' (bah-GAH-zheng).

exampleSentence: Nós decidimos alugar um carro para explorar a costa.
exampleTranslation: We decided to rent a car to explore the coast.
contextNotes: Used for renting vehicles, apartments, or equipment. The noun form is 'aluguel' (Brazil) or 'aluguer' (Portugal).

exampleSentence: O horário de partida do trem foi alterado.
exampleTranslation: The train's departure time was changed.
contextNotes: Commonly seen on airport and station boards, opposite of 'chegada' (arrival).

exampleSentence: Desejo a você uma boa viagem!
exampleTranslation: I wish you a good trip!
contextNotes: The verb form is 'viajar' (to travel). This is one of the most fundamental words for the theme.

exampleSentence: Tivemos que declarar os bens na alfândega.
exampleTranslation: We had to declare the goods at customs.
contextNotes: Refers to the government agency or area at borders/airports where goods and baggage are inspected.

exampleSentence: Nosso voo tem uma escala longa em Madrid.
exampleTranslation: Our flight has a long layover in Madrid.
contextNotes: Crucial term when booking international flights, indicating a stop between the origin and final destination.

exampleSentence: A hospedagem no hotel era cara, mas valeu a pena.
exampleTranslation: The accommodation at the hotel was expensive, but it was worth it.
contextNotes: A general term covering hotels, hostels, B&Bs, etc. The verb is 'se hospedar' (to stay/lodge).

exampleSentence: Você já planejou o itinerário da nossa viagem pela Europa?
exampleTranslation: Have you already planned the itinerary for our trip through Europe?
contextNotes: Refers to the planned route or schedule of a journey.

exampleSentence: É necessário despachar a bagagem antes de ir para o portão.
exampleTranslation: It is necessary to check the luggage before going to the gate.
contextNotes: Specifically used for checking luggage onto a flight. It can also mean 'to dispatch' or 'to handle paperwork'.

exampleSentence: A logística de transporte em cidades grandes é um desafio constante.
exampleTranslation: The logistics of transportation in large cities is a constant challenge.
contextNotes: Used in a broader, more formal sense, referring to the complex coordination and planning of resources, routes, and schedules for travel or supply.

exampleSentence: O sol está muito forte hoje.
exampleTranslation: The sun is very strong today.
contextNotes: Used universally in Portuguese. 'Estar com sol' means 'it is sunny'.

exampleSentence: Vai chover amanhã de manhã.
exampleTranslation: It is going to rain tomorrow morning.
contextNotes: The verb form is 'chover' (to rain). 'Está chovendo' means 'It is raining'.

exampleSentence: O vento forte derrubou a árvore.
exampleTranslation: The strong wind knocked down the tree.
contextNotes: Often used with the verb 'fazer' (to make/do) when describing the weather: 'Está fazendo vento' (It is windy).

exampleSentence: O céu está limpo e azul.
exampleTranslation: The sky is clear and blue.
contextNotes: Also means 'heaven'. The plural is 'céus'.

exampleSentence: Há muitas árvores na floresta amazônica.
exampleTranslation: There are many trees in the Amazon rainforest.
contextNotes: A fundamental word for nature vocabulary. Distinguish from 'madeira' (wood/lumber).

exampleSentence: Vamos passar o fim de semana na praia.
exampleTranslation: We are going to spend the weekend at the beach.
contextNotes: Extremely common word in Brazil and Portugal due to extensive coastlines. Often associated with leisure.

exampleSentence: Qual é a temperatura máxima prevista para hoje?
exampleTranslation: What is the maximum temperature forecast for today?
contextNotes: Used exactly like the English equivalent when discussing weather or body heat.

exampleSentence: Gosto de caminhar nas montanhas.
exampleTranslation: I like to hike in the mountains.
contextNotes: A synonym for a smaller hill might be 'morro' (common in Rio de Janeiro) or 'colina'.

exampleSentence: Raramente cai neve no Brasil.
exampleTranslation: It rarely snows in Brazil.
contextNotes: While rare in most of Brazil, it is essential vocabulary. The verb is 'nevar' (to snow).

exampleSentence: A umidade do ar está muito alta nesta época do ano.
exampleTranslation: The air humidity is very high at this time of year.
contextNotes: Crucial word in tropical climates like Brazil, often discussed in weather reports.

exampleSentence: Está caindo uma garoa fina agora.
exampleTranslation: A fine drizzle is falling now.
contextNotes: Specific term for very light, persistent rain, especially common in cities like São Paulo.

exampleSentence: Durante a tempestade, vimos muitos raios no horizonte.
exampleTranslation: During the storm, we saw a lot of lightning on the horizon.
contextNotes: The singular 'raio' means ray, beam, or lightning bolt. Often used in the plural when describing a storm.

exampleSentence: A estiagem prolongada causou problemas na agricultura.
exampleTranslation: The prolonged drought caused problems in agriculture.
contextNotes: Refers specifically to a period of dryness, often used in environmental and agricultural contexts.

exampleSentence: A Mata Atlântica é um dos biomas mais ameaçados do mundo.
exampleTranslation: The Atlantic Forest is one of the most threatened biomes in the world.
contextNotes: A crucial geographical and environmental term referring to the coastal rainforest biome of Brazil.

exampleSentence: O voo foi cancelado devido às intempéries.
exampleTranslation: The flight was canceled due to the inclement weather.
contextNotes: Formal term used to describe severe or rough weather conditions (rain, wind, snow, etc.). Often used in bureaucratic or news contexts.

exampleSentence: Meu cachorro gosta de brincar no parque.
exampleTranslation: My dog likes to play in the park.
contextNotes: In Brazil, 'cachorro' is standard. In Portugal, 'cão' is often preferred, though 'cachorro' is used for puppies.

exampleSentence: O gato está dormindo na janela.
exampleTranslation: The cat is sleeping on the window.
contextNotes: A very common and essential word. 'Gata' is the feminine form (female cat).

exampleSentence: Temos um peixe dourado no aquário.
exampleTranslation: We have a goldfish in the aquarium.
contextNotes: 'Peixe' refers to the live animal. When referring to fish as food, the same word is used.

exampleSentence: Que pássaro bonito está cantando!
exampleTranslation: What a beautiful bird is singing!
contextNotes: This is the general term for bird. Specific types (like 'papagaio' - parrot) are also common pets.

exampleSentence: Você precisa colocar a coleira no cão antes de sair.
exampleTranslation: You need to put the collar on the dog before going out.
contextNotes: Essential vocabulary for dog owners. Often paired with 'guia' (leash).

exampleSentence: Comprei um saco grande de ração para o meu gato.
exampleTranslation: I bought a big bag of kibble for my cat.
contextNotes: This specific term refers to dry pet food (kibble). Wet food might be called 'comida úmida'.

exampleSentence: Precisamos levar o coelho ao veterinário.
exampleTranslation: We need to take the rabbit to the vet.
contextNotes: Shortened forms like 'vet' are not typically used in Portuguese; the full word is standard.

exampleSentence: O cachorro destruiu o brinquedo novo.
exampleTranslation: The dog destroyed the new toy.
contextNotes: Used for both human and animal toys. For pets, sometimes specified as 'brinquedo para animais'.

exampleSentence: Muitas pessoas preferem adotar um animal de estimação.
exampleTranslation: Many people prefer to adopt a pet.
contextNotes: The concept of animal adoption ('adoção') is very strong in Portuguese-speaking cultures, often promoted over buying.

exampleSentence: Foi um longo processo domesticar os cavalos.
exampleTranslation: It was a long process to domesticate the horses.
contextNotes: Used more generally for the historical taming of species, less often for individual pets unless they are wild rescues.

exampleSentence: A pelagem do gato siamês é curta e macia.
exampleTranslation: The Siamese cat's coat is short and soft.
contextNotes: While 'pelo' means hair/fur, 'pelagem' refers specifically to the overall coat texture, color, and condition of the animal.

exampleSentence: A castração é importante para o controle populacional de animais de rua.
exampleTranslation: Neutering is important for the population control of street animals.
contextNotes: A crucial term in animal welfare and pet ownership discussions. Often used in public health campaigns.

exampleSentence: O veterinário está estudando o comportamento agressivo do filhote.
exampleTranslation: The vet is studying the puppy's aggressive behavior.
contextNotes: A general term applicable to humans and animals, essential for discussing training or health issues.

exampleSentence: A raiva é uma zoonose grave que pode ser transmitida aos humanos.
exampleTranslation: Rabies is a serious zoonosis that can be transmitted to humans.
contextNotes: This term is used in scientific, medical, and public health contexts when discussing diseases shared between animals and humans.

exampleSentence: O ativista luta pelo bem-estar animal em fazendas industriais.
exampleTranslation: The activist fights for animal welfare on industrial farms.
contextNotes: A formal, compound term used in legal, ethical, and activist discussions regarding the quality of life for animals.

exampleSentence: O futebol é o esporte mais popular no Brasil.
exampleTranslation: Soccer is the most popular sport in Brazil.
contextNotes: The most important sport in Brazil. Always use 'futebol' for soccer; 'futebol americano' is used for American football.

exampleSentence: Eu faço natação três vezes por semana.
exampleTranslation: I go swimming three times a week.
contextNotes: A very common hobby and competitive sport. Note the nasal diphthong 'ão'.

exampleSentence: Gosto de ler livros de ficção científica.
exampleTranslation: I like to read science fiction books.
contextNotes: A fundamental verb for describing a common hobby. Conjugates irregularly in some tenses.

exampleSentence: Vou à academia todas as manhãs.
exampleTranslation: I go to the gym every morning.
contextNotes: In Portugal, 'ginásio' is also common, but 'academia' is the standard term in Brazil for a fitness center.

exampleSentence: Nós caminhamos no parque depois do trabalho.
exampleTranslation: We walk in the park after work.
contextNotes: A versatile verb used for light exercise (walking) or more strenuous activity (hiking/trekking).

exampleSentence: Qual é o seu time de futebol favorito?
exampleTranslation: What is your favorite soccer team?
contextNotes: Used universally in sports contexts. In Portugal, 'equipa' is more common, but 'time' is standard in Brazil.

exampleSentence: Minha filha adora desenhar animais.
exampleTranslation: My daughter loves to draw animals.
contextNotes: A common hobby verb. Used specifically for drawing pictures or sketches.

exampleSentence: O treino de hoje foi muito intenso.
exampleTranslation: Today's workout was very intense.
contextNotes: Refers to a specific practice session or workout routine. The verb form is 'treinar' (to train).

exampleSentence: Vamos dar um passeio de bicicleta no domingo.
exampleTranslation: Let's go for a bike ride on Sunday.
contextNotes: A broad term for a leisure activity or outing. Can be a short walk, drive, or ride.

exampleSentence: O judô é uma modalidade olímpica popular.
exampleTranslation: Judo is a popular Olympic discipline.
contextNotes: More formal than 'esporte'. Used when distinguishing between different types of sports or activities within a competition.

exampleSentence: Ele precisa aprimorar sua técnica de arremesso.
exampleTranslation: He needs to refine his throwing technique.
contextNotes: A useful verb in the context of training and skill development, implying continuous improvement.

exampleSentence: A torcida brasileira é conhecida por ser muito apaixonada.
exampleTranslation: The Brazilian fan base is known for being very passionate.
contextNotes: Crucial cultural word. Refers collectively to the supporters of a team. 'Torcedor(a)' is an individual fan.

exampleSentence: No meu tempo de lazer, eu gosto de cozinhar.
exampleTranslation: In my leisure time, I like to cook.
contextNotes: A formal and common term used to discuss hobbies and activities done for pleasure outside of work.

exampleSentence: O atleta conseguiu superar seu recorde pessoal.
exampleTranslation: The athlete managed to surpass his personal record.
contextNotes: Used frequently in motivational contexts, both in sports and personal development.

exampleSentence: A nova metodologia de treinamento físico exige mais resistência aeróbica.
exampleTranslation: The new physical training methodology requires more aerobic endurance.
contextNotes: A high-level term used when discussing the structured approach or theory behind advanced training or coaching.

exampleSentence: Eu preciso usar o computador para enviar um email.
exampleTranslation: I need to use the computer to send an email.
contextNotes: The standard term for computer in both Brazil and Portugal. Often shortened informally to 'PC' (pê-cê).

exampleSentence: A internet está lenta hoje.
exampleTranslation: The internet is slow today.
contextNotes: While 'internet' is a loanword, it is treated as feminine in Portuguese (a internet).

exampleSentence: Meu celular está sem bateria.
exampleTranslation: My cell phone is out of battery.
contextNotes: This is the common term in Brazil. In Portugal, 'telemóvel' (teh-leh-MOH-vel) is preferred.

exampleSentence: Você recebeu minha mensagem de texto?
exampleTranslation: Did you receive my text message?
contextNotes: Used for both physical letters/notes and digital texts (like WhatsApp or SMS).

exampleSentence: Nunca compartilhe sua senha com ninguém.
exampleTranslation: Never share your password with anyone.
contextNotes: Essential word for digital security. Also means 'sign' or 'signal' in other contexts, but primarily 'password' in tech.

exampleSentence: Qual é o seu aplicativo favorito?
exampleTranslation: What is your favorite app?
contextNotes: Commonly shortened to 'app' (pronounced AH-pi) in casual speech, but 'aplicativo' is the formal term.

exampleSentence: Tente conectar o cabo USB na porta traseira.
exampleTranslation: Try to connect the USB cable to the back port.
contextNotes: Used for physical and digital connections (e.g., connecting to Wi-Fi: 'conectar-se ao Wi-Fi').

exampleSentence: As redes sociais mudaram a forma como nos comunicamos.
exampleTranslation: Social networks changed the way we communicate.
contextNotes: Always used in the plural ('redes sociais') when referring to platforms like Instagram or Facebook.

exampleSentence: Preciso carregar meu telefone antes de sair.
exampleTranslation: I need to charge my phone before leaving.
contextNotes: Also means 'to carry' or 'to load' (data), but in the context of phones/laptops, it means 'to charge'.

exampleSentence: Qual navegador você usa para acessar a web?
exampleTranslation: Which browser do you use to access the web?
contextNotes: Derived from 'navegar' (to navigate). Refers specifically to web browsers (Chrome, Firefox, etc.).

exampleSentence: O armazenamento em nuvem é muito conveniente.
exampleTranslation: Cloud storage is very convenient.
contextNotes: Used universally for data storage (HD, cloud, memory card). The verb is 'armazenar'.

exampleSentence: O WhatsApp usa criptografia de ponta a ponta.
exampleTranslation: WhatsApp uses end-to-end encryption.
contextNotes: A technical term that has become common in everyday conversations regarding privacy and secure messaging apps.

exampleSentence: Você deve instalar a última atualização de segurança.
exampleTranslation: You should install the latest security update.
contextNotes: Refers to software or system updates. The verb is 'atualizar' (to update/to modernize).

exampleSentence: A transmissão ao vivo requer uma boa largura de banda.
exampleTranslation: Live streaming requires good bandwidth.
contextNotes: A key technical term used when discussing internet speed and data transfer capacity.

exampleSentence: O governo prometeu investir na infraestrutura digital do país.
exampleTranslation: The government promised to invest in the country's digital infrastructure.
contextNotes: A high-level term used when discussing the foundational systems (cables, towers, data centers) that support communication networks.

exampleSentence: A felicidade está nas pequenas coisas da vida.
exampleTranslation: Happiness is in the small things in life.
contextNotes: A fundamental abstract noun. Often used in philosophical contexts or simple greetings (e.g., 'Muita felicidade!' - Much happiness!).

exampleSentence: Ele ficou muito triste depois da notícia.
exampleTranslation: He became very sad after the news.
contextNotes: Used for both temporary sadness and deeper melancholy. It is invariable in gender (o homem triste, a mulher triste).

exampleSentence: Senti muita raiva quando perdi o voo.
exampleTranslation: I felt a lot of anger when I missed the flight.
contextNotes: The standard word for anger. The verb form is 'ficar com raiva' (to get angry) or 'sentir raiva' (to feel anger).

exampleSentence: Tenho medo de altura.
exampleTranslation: I have fear of heights.
contextNotes: In Portuguese, you 'have' fear ('ter medo'), unlike English where you 'are' afraid. 'Medo' is a very common word.

exampleSentence: Ela está apaixonada pelo novo colega de trabalho.
exampleTranslation: She is in love with the new coworker.
contextNotes: Stronger than 'gostar' (to like). It specifically denotes being romantically in love or having a strong passion for something.

exampleSentence: Tivemos uma grande surpresa no nosso aniversário.
exampleTranslation: We had a big surprise on our anniversary.
contextNotes: Can be used for both the feeling (a surpresa) and the unexpected event (uma surpresa).

exampleSentence: É importante manter a calma em situações difíceis.
exampleTranslation: It is important to remain calm in difficult situations.
contextNotes: A basic adjective describing a state of tranquility. Used with the verb 'estar' (to be temporarily) or 'ser' (to be inherently).

exampleSentence: Fiquei com muita vergonha de ter caído na frente de todos.
exampleTranslation: I felt very ashamed/embarrassed about falling in front of everyone.
contextNotes: Similar to 'medo,' you 'have' shame ('ter vergonha'). 'Que vergonha!' means 'How embarrassing!'

exampleSentence: Minha ansiedade aumenta antes de uma viagem.
exampleTranslation: My anxiety increases before a trip.
contextNotes: A very common term in modern Portuguese, referring to nervousness, worry, or clinical anxiety.

exampleSentence: O desânimo dele após a derrota era visível.
exampleTranslation: His discouragement after the defeat was visible.
contextNotes: A feeling of low spirits or loss of motivation. Often contrasted with 'ânimo' (spirit/courage).

exampleSentence: Senti um grande alívio quando o exame deu negativo.
exampleTranslation: I felt a great relief when the test came back negative.
contextNotes: Used when a stressful situation ends. The verb form is 'aliviar' (to relieve).

exampleSentence: Ele guarda mágoa do pai por causa de promessas não cumpridas.
exampleTranslation: He holds resentment toward his father because of unfulfilled promises.
contextNotes: Refers to a lasting emotional wound or deep grievance, often involving betrayal or disappointment. Stronger than simple sadness.

exampleSentence: Tenho muito orgulho de ser brasileiro.
exampleTranslation: I have a lot of pride in being Brazilian.
contextNotes: Can be positive (self-respect, national pride) or negative (arrogance, hubris), depending on the context.

exampleSentence: O silêncio na sala causou um profundo confrangimento entre os presentes.
exampleTranslation: The silence in the room caused deep distress/awkwardness among those present.
contextNotes: A formal or literary term for acute discomfort, deep embarrassment, or moral anguish. Less common in daily speech than 'vergonha'.

exampleSentence: Sinto uma forte nostalgia dos tempos de infância.
exampleTranslation: I feel a strong nostalgia for childhood times.
contextNotes: While related to the famous Portuguese concept of 'saudade,' nostalgia is a direct borrowing and refers specifically to longing for the past.

exampleSentence: Eu sou brasileiro e ela é médica.
exampleTranslation: I am Brazilian and she is a doctor.
contextNotes: Ser is used for permanent characteristics, identity, origin, time, and occupation. It is one of the two main verbs for 'to be' in Portuguese.

exampleSentence: Nós estamos cansados e o livro está na mesa.
exampleTranslation: We are tired and the book is on the table.
contextNotes: Estar is used for temporary states, feelings, location, and actions in progress (like 'estou falando'). Essential for expressing condition.

exampleSentence: Você tem um carro novo?
exampleTranslation: Do you have a new car?
contextNotes: Ter is also used idiomatically to express age ('ter X anos') and certain physical states ('ter fome' - to be hungry).

exampleSentence: Eles vão ao cinema amanhã.
exampleTranslation: They are going to the movie theater tomorrow.
contextNotes: Highly irregular verb. It is also used as an auxiliary verb to form the immediate future ('ir + infinitive').

exampleSentence: O que você vai fazer hoje?
exampleTranslation: What are you going to do today?
contextNotes: Fazer is used in many common expressions, including describing the weather ('Faz calor' - It is hot) and time duration.

exampleSentence: Podemos falar sobre isso mais tarde?
exampleTranslation: Can we talk about this later?
contextNotes: Used to express ability, permission, or possibility. The conditional form ('poderia') is used for polite requests.

exampleSentence: Eu vou dar um presente para minha mãe.
exampleTranslation: I am going to give a present to my mother.
contextNotes: Irregular verb. Also used in common phrases like 'dar certo' (to work out/go well) and 'dar um jeito' (to figure out a way).

exampleSentence: O que ele disse sobre o plano?
exampleTranslation: What did he say about the plan?
contextNotes: Highly irregular, especially in the present tense (Eu digo). Be careful not to confuse it with 'falar' (to speak).

exampleSentence: Você sabe onde fica o museu?
exampleTranslation: Do you know where the museum is located?
contextNotes: Contrasts with 'conhecer' (to know/be familiar with people, places, or things). Saber relates to knowledge or skills.
