exampleSentence: Apesar da dificuldade, conseguimos terminar o projeto a tempo.
exampleTranslation: Despite the difficulty, we managed to finish the project on time.
contextNotes: Often used interchangeably with 'poder' when meaning 'to be able to,' but it implies overcoming an obstacle or achieving a goal.

exampleSentence: Parece que vai chover mais tarde.
exampleTranslation: It seems like it's going to rain later.
contextNotes: Often used impersonally ('Parece que...') or reflexively ('Ele se parece com o pai' - He looks like his father).

exampleSentence: O trabalho árduo o tornou um especialista na área.
exampleTranslation: The hard work made him become an expert in the field.
contextNotes: Frequently used reflexively ('tornar-se') to mean 'to become,' emphasizing a change in status or condition.

exampleSentence: A nova lei exige que todos os documentos sejam verificados.
exampleTranslation: The new law requires that all documents be verified.
contextNotes: A strong verb implying necessity or mandatory compliance. Often followed by the subjunctive mood.

exampleSentence: Não se deve pressupor que todos concordarão com a proposta.
exampleTranslation: One should not assume that everyone will agree with the proposal.
contextNotes: A formal verb used in academic or professional contexts, meaning to take something for granted or assume its prior existence.

exampleSentence: A empresa espera auferir lucros significativos neste trimestre.
exampleTranslation: The company expects to yield significant profits this quarter.
contextNotes: A highly formal verb, almost exclusively used in financial, legal, or bureaucratic language. Rarely used in casual conversation.

exampleSentence: A casa é muito grande e tem um jardim bonito.
exampleTranslation: The house is very big and has a beautiful garden.
contextNotes: Can mean 'big' (size) or 'great' (quality). When placed before a singular noun, it often shortens to 'grande' (e.g., um grande homem - a great man).

exampleSentence: Ele comprou um carro pequeno para a cidade.
exampleTranslation: He bought a small car for the city.
contextNotes: Must agree in gender and number (pequena, pequenos, pequenas). Often used with the diminutive suffix '-inho' (e.g., pequenininho) to emphasize smallness or affection.

exampleSentence: Este restaurante tem comida muito boa.
exampleTranslation: This restaurant has very good food.
contextNotes: The masculine form is 'bom' (singular) and 'bons' (plural). The feminine form is 'boa' (singular) and 'boas' (plural). It is often used as an interjection, 'Que bom!' (That's good!).

exampleSentence: Não é um bom sinal; na verdade, é um mau presságio.
exampleTranslation: It is not a good sign; in fact, it is a bad omen.
contextNotes: Must agree in gender and number (mau/má, maus/más). Note the difference between 'mau' (adjective, bad) and 'mal' (adverb, badly/poorly).

exampleSentence: A prova de matemática foi muito fácil hoje.
exampleTranslation: The math test was very easy today.
contextNotes: This adjective is invariant in gender (it's always fácil) but changes in number (fáceis).

exampleSentence: Aprender um novo idioma pode ser difícil no começo.
exampleTranslation: Learning a new language can be difficult at first.
contextNotes: Like 'fácil', this word is invariant in gender but changes in number (difíceis). Used commonly to describe tasks, concepts, or people.

exampleSentence: Eu comprei um celular novo e estou adorando.
exampleTranslation: I bought a new cell phone and I am loving it.
contextNotes: When placed before the noun, it usually means 'newly acquired' (e.g., meu novo carro). When placed after, it can mean 'brand new' or 'young' (e.g., um carro novo).

exampleSentence: Aquele prédio é muito velho, mas ainda está em boas condições.
exampleTranslation: That building is very old, but it is still in good condition.
contextNotes: Used for objects and people. For people, 'idoso' (elderly) is often considered more respectful than 'velho'.

exampleSentence: Ela estava muito feliz por ter passado no exame.
exampleTranslation: She was very happy to have passed the exam.
contextNotes: Invariant in gender. Plural form is 'felizes'. Often used in greetings, 'Feliz Natal!' (Merry Christmas!).

exampleSentence: O planejamento é essencial para o sucesso do projeto.
exampleTranslation: Planning is essential for the success of the project.
contextNotes: A formal adjective used to denote necessity or importance. Plural is 'essenciais'.

exampleSentence: Precisamos estar conscientes dos nossos direitos e deveres.
exampleTranslation: We need to be aware of our rights and duties.
contextNotes: Invariant in gender. Often followed by the preposition 'de' (consciente de algo/alguém).

exampleSentence: A reunião subsequente tratará dos resultados financeiros.
exampleTranslation: The subsequent meeting will deal with the financial results.
contextNotes: A more formal adjective, typically used in written communication or professional contexts to indicate something that comes immediately after.

exampleSentence: A influência da família foi preponderante na sua decisão.
exampleTranslation: The family's influence was overriding in his decision.
contextNotes: Used to describe something that has greater weight, importance, or influence than others. Invariant in gender.

exampleSentence: De acordo com a legislação vigente, a multa é obrigatória.
exampleTranslation: According to the current legislation, the fine is mandatory.
contextNotes: Used almost exclusively in legal, governmental, or formal business contexts to refer to laws, rules, or contracts that are currently active.

exampleSentence: A beleza da paisagem era inefável, além das palavras.
exampleTranslation: The beauty of the landscape was ineffable, beyond words.
contextNotes: A highly literary or philosophical term, used to describe something too profound, beautiful, or extreme to be expressed in words. Plural is 'inefáveis'.
